text: The 2003–04 LEN Euroleague is the 41st edition of LEN's premier competition for men's water polo clubs. It ran from 17 September 2003 to 29 May 2004, and it is contested by 38 teams. The Final Four (semifinals, final, and third place game) took place on May 28 and May 29 in Budapest. ==Preliminary round== {| class="wikitable" |- !Key to colors in group tables |- style="background:#cfc;" |Group winners and runners-up advanced to the Quarter-finals |} ===Group A=== ===Group B=== ===Group C=== ===Group D=== ==Knockout stage== ===Quarter-finals=== The first legs were played on 14 April, and the second legs were played on 28 April 2004. ===Final Four (Budapest)=== Hajós Alfréd Nemzeti Sportuszoda, Budapest, Hungary ====Final standings==== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! width=25| !! width=220|Team |- | 15px ||align=left| Honvéd |- | 15px ||align=left| Jadran Herceg Novi |- | 15px ||align=left| Primorje |- | ||align=left| Šturm 2002 |} ==== Final Four 2004 MVP ==== Péter Biros (Honvéd) {| style="text-align: center; margin-top: 2em; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto" |- |István Gergely, Olivér Kovács, Miklós Bereczki, Rajmund Fodor, Attila Bárány, Gergely Kiss, Márton Szivós, Tamás Molnár, Attila Vári, Viktor Paján, Sándor Sugár, Péter Biros, Zoltán Kovács, Ottó Frikk |- |Head Coach |- |István Kovács |} == See also == * 2003–04 LEN Cup Category:LEN Champions League seasons Champions League Category:2003 in water polo Category:2004 in water polo
title: 2003–04 LEN Euroleague
